IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: TO FACILITATE AND PROMOTE PHILANTHROPY THROUGH DONOR ADVISED FUNDS
IRS990.MissionDesc: THE JEWISH COMMUNAL FUND FACILITATES AND PROMOTES CHARITABLE GIVING TO SECTARIAN AND NONSECTARIAN ORGANIZATIONS THROUGH DONOR-ADVISED FUNDS AND PROVIDES SUPPORT TO JEWISH ORGANIZATIONS IN NEW YORK. JCF ENABLES INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES TO ACHIEVE THEIR PHILANTHROPIC GOALS SIMPLY AND EFFECTIVELY, WITH FULL CONFIDENTIALITY. JCF ESTABLISHED THREE DISTINCT TYPES OF PHILANTHROPIC FUNDS - (i) UNDESIGNATED FUNDS: WHERE THE PRIVILEGE OF GRANT RECOMMENDATION IS GIVEN TO THE DONOR (AND HIS OR HER DESIGNEES) AND THE DISTRIBUTION OF PRINCIPAL AND INCOME IS GOVERNED BY JCF GRANT GUIDELINES. GRANT MAKING IS SUBJECT TO THE APPROVAL OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES AND THE CHARITABLE DISTRIBUTION COMMITTEE. (ii) DESIGNATED FUNDS: WHERE THE BENEFICIARIES AND THE SCHEDULE OF DISTRIBUTIONS ARE ESTABLISHED AT THE TIME OF THE GIFT AND ARE APPROVED BY THE CHARITABLE DISTRIBUTION COMMITTEE. (iii) ENDOWMENT FUNDS: IN WHICH THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES AND CHARITABLE DISTRIBUTION COMMITTEE HAVE THE RESPONSIBILITY OF GRANT MAK
IRS990.Desc: JCF'S PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY IS TO SERVE DONORS WHO HAVE ENTRUSTED IT WITH THEIR CHARITABLE DOLLARS. JCF TAKES THIS RESPONSIBILITY VERY SERIOUSLY AND IS COMMITTED TO TREATING ITS DONORS WITH THE UTMOST INTEGRITY AND RESPECT. JCF HANDLES ALL THE ADMINISTRATIVE RESPONSIBILITIES FOR EACH DONOR-ADVISED FUND AND PROVIDES DONORS WITH REGULAR REPORTS ON CONTRIBUTIONS, GRANTS, INVESTMENT INCOME, FUND BALANCE AND ALL OTHER ACTIVITY RELATED TO THE FUND. JCF HONORS ITS COMMITMENT TO DONORS BY PROVIDING SERVICES THAT MAKE THEIR CHARITABLE GIVING ADMINISTRATIVELY EFFICIENT, ECONOMICALLY ADVANTAGEOUS, AND PERSONALLY REWARDING. THESE INCLUDE SIMPLIFYING THE GRANT-MAKING PROCESS SO THAT DONOR CONTRIBUTIONS FLOW QUICKLY AND EASILY IN THE CHARITABLE STREAM, OFFERING A CHOICE OF INVESTMENT VEHICLES DESIGNED TO HELP DONORS' CHARITABLE DOLLARS GROW, KEEPING DONORS INFORMED ABOUT CHANGING TAX LAWS THAT MAY IMPACT THEIR CHARITABLE GIVING, SUGGESTING WAYS FOR DONORS TO INCORPORATE PHILANTHROPY INTO THEIR ESTATE AND GIFT PLANNING, EDUCATING DONORS ABOUT GRANT-MAKING STRATEGIES AND COMMUNAL PHILANTHROPIC RESOURCES, SAFEGUARDING DONOR CONFIDENTIALITY, AND FACILITATING INTERGENERATIONAL PHILANTHROPY.

ContractorName.PersonNm: PWP GROWTH EQUITY FUND II LP

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: USE OF ENDOWMENT FUND: The Jewish Communal Fund's Special Gifts Fund is a fund from which grants are made to support projects and/or organizations in the Jewish community recommended by UJA-Federation of New York. The Fund's spending policy is up to 5% of the twelve preceding calendar quarters' rolling average of the fund balance. Grant proposals are submitted by UJA-Federation to the Jewish Communal Fund Special Gifts Fund Committee based on the following criteria: (i) Proposals can be for both capital and programmatic purposes, (ii) Proposals should have a high impact on the Jewish community, be accompanied by agency budgets; and (iii) organizations receiving multi-year renewable grants must provide annual status updates. Projects selected by the Special Gifts Fund Committee are submitted to the Jewish Communal Fund Board of Trustees for approval.

INCOME TAXes Disclosure: JCF is subject to the provisions of the Financial Accounting Standards Board's (the "FASB") Accounting Standards Codification ("ASC") Topic 740, Income Taxes, relating to accounting and reporting for uncertainty in income taxes. JCF is subject to potential unrelated business income tax relating to its investment activities; however, since JCF has always accrued a liability related to this tax and because of JCF's general tax-exempt status, management believes ASC Topic 740 has not had, and is not expected to have, a material impact on JCF's consolidated financial statements.

Procedures for Foreign Grantmaking: Jewish Communal Fund utilizes various agencies who perform equivalency determinations for foreign charities. Through the due diligence performed by these agencies, JCF is able to rely on their determinations that the foreign charities would qualify as the equivalent of a U.S. charity that is in good standing and that is not listed on the U.S. Department of the Treasury OFAC sanctions list. JCF does not monitor the usage of grants made to qualified charities as listed above. Part I, Line 3, Column (F) Amounts are reported on the accrual basis.
While Jewish Communal Fund did own this type of investment during the tax year, the threshold for filing Form 5471 was not met, and therefore no such filing was necessary.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Each grantee organization recommended by donors is reviewed by JCF to verify its tax-exempt status and official mailing address. All grants issued by JCF are made to organizations that qualify as tax-exempt under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and are classified as either public charities as described in Sections 509(a)(1), (a)(2), or (a)(3) of the Code or private operating foundations as described in Section 4942(j)(3) of the Code. JCF does not make grants to individuals, private non-operating foundations, "controlled" Type I or Type II supporting organizations, or Type III supporting organizations that are not functionally integrated, or any organization that is listed on the U.S. Department of the Treasury's OFAC Sanctions List. JCF does not monitor the usage of grants made to qualified charities as listed above.

Supplemental Nonqualified Retirement Plan: This is a supplemental nonqualified retirement plan for the Executive Vice President/CEO and the Senior Vice President/COO. Contributions to the plan made by JCF during the calendar year 2017 totaled $36,500.

DUE TO THE TAX CUTS AND JOBS ACT, JCF WAS SUBJECT TO UBIT ON THE DISALLOWED TRANSIT BENEFITS AND ACCORDINGLY INCLUDED THIS AMOUNT ON ITS FORM 990-T. PART VI, LINE 6 and 7A, GOVERNING BODY AND MANAGEMENT, MEMBERS: THE JEWISH COMMUNAL FUND HAS ONE MEMBER. THE MEMBER PARTICIPATES IN THE ELECTION OF TRUSTEES AND HAS THE AUTHORITY TO TERMINATE TRUSTEES WITH OR WITHOUT CAUSE AT ANY TIME. PART VI, LINE 11A, PROCESS FOR REVIEW OF FORM 990: THE AUDIT COMMITTEE, EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE, AND FULL BOARD OF TRUSTEES REVIEW AND APPROVE THE FORM 990 prior to its submission to the Internal Revenue Service.

CONFLICTS OF INTEREST POLICY: JEWISH COMMUNAL FUND REGULARLY AND CONSISTENTLY MONITORS AND ENFORCES COMPLIANCE WITH THE CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY BY REQUIRING ALL OFFICERS, TRUSTEES, AND MEMBERS OF SENIOR MANAGEMENT TO COMPLETE THE RELATED PARTIES AND ETHICAL GUIDELINES DOCUMENTS ANNUALLY. THE COMPLETED DOCUMENTS ARE REVIEWED BY MANAGEMENT AND THE CHAIR OF THE AUDIT COMMITTEE FOR POTENTIAL CONFLICTS.

EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION POLICY: COMPENSATION FOR THE EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT AND OTHER KEY EMPLOYEES IS ESTABLISHED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE, WHICH CONSISTS OF INDEPENDENT TRUSTEES. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE USES COMPARABLE DATA FROM SIMILAR ORGANIZATIONS, AS WELL AS A REPORT AND ADVICE FROM AN EXTERNAL Independent executive compensation consultant, TO DETERMINE CURRENT COMPENSATION LEVELS. THESE AMOUNTS ARE PRESENTED TO THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE AND TO THE FULL BOARD OF TRUSTEES FOR FINAL APPROVAL.

PUBLIC INSPECTION: JCF Makes Available its Form 990 on its website and upon request. Its Form 1023 and Form 990-T are available upon request. PART VI, Line 19, DISCLOSURE JCF MAKES AVAILABLE ITS FINANCIAL STATEMENTS ON ITS WEBSITE AND UPON REQUEST. IT DOES NOT MAKE AVAILABLE ITS GOVERNING DOCUMENTS OR CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY.
